body_content.explanation: to put something valuable, especially money, in a bank or safe (= a strong box or cupboard with locks) again, for a second, third, etc. time:
examples: If a guest wishes to redeposit valuables, a new receipt must be issued every time.
Just withdraw £20, then redeposit it back to the same account.

body_content.explanation: to leave something, especially a layer of a substance, in a place again, after it has been moved:
examples: It is possible to identify past sea levels with some accuracy using redeposited shells.
If these chemicals are introduced into the water, they can be redeposited on shorelines, travel downstream, and accumulate in fish.
